title: SB 354
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 7522.02 of the Government Code is amended. On January 1, 2013, this article applies to all state and local public retirement systems and their participating employers, including various specific systems and individual retirement plans offered by public employers. This article applies to state and local public retirement systems, including specific systems and individual retirement plans offered by public employers, subject to the Internal Revenue Code and California Constitution. Compliance with relevant tax laws is required for administration. The article applies to state and local public retirement systems, including specific systems and individual retirement plans offered by public employers, subject to tax laws. However, certain entities excluded by the California Constitution are not affected by this article if they are participating employers in a retirement system governed by state statute. Any retirement plan approved before January 1, 2013, by voters of excluded entities remains unaffected. The article applies to state and local public retirement systems, excluding certain entities protected by the California Constitution. Public employees under Section 5333(b) of Title 49 of the United States Code are exempt until a federal court rules otherwise or until January 1, 2016. The article exempts public employees specified in Section 5333(b) of Title 49 of the United States Code if a federal court upholds the Secretary of Labor's determination. Additionally, the article does not apply to a multiemployer plan regulated by the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 if the public employer joined before January 1, 2013. The article exempts public employees specified in Section 5333(b) of Title 49 of the United States Code if a federal court upholds the Secretary of Labor's determination. It also does not apply to a multiemployer plan authorized by Section 302(c)(5) of the federal Taft-Hartley Act if the public employer began participation before January 1, 2013, and the plan is regulated by the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The benefit plan required by this article applies to new public employees as defined in Section 7522.04. The benefit plan required by this article applies to public employees who are new members as defined in Section 7522.04. Individuals who were employed by a public employer before January 1, 2013, and then became employed by a subsequent public employer on or after January 1, 2013, will be subject to the retirement plan available to employees of the subsequent employer who were hired before December 31, 2012, under certain conditions. An individual employed before January 1, 2013, who changes positions without a break in employment and joins a different defined benefit plan in another public retirement system will be subject to the new plan as if they were hired before December 31, 2012. If a public employer offers a defined benefit pension plan with a lower benefit factor before January 1, 2013, they can continue to do so without being subject to certain requirements. However, if they adopt a new defined benefit formula on or after January 1, 2013, it must comply with the new requirements. The employer must ensure that any new defined benefit formula adopted after January 1, 2013, complies with the requirements of the article or is certified to have no greater risk or cost than the previous formula. New members can only participate in the lower cost formula in place before 2013. The new defined benefit formula must comply with article requirements or be certified as low risk/cost. New members can only join the lower cost formula in place before 2013 or an approved alternative. If a public employer offers a retirement benefit plan before January 1, 2013, consisting solely of a defined contribution plan, they can continue with that plan. However, if they adopt a new defined benefit pension plan or formula after January 1, 2013, it must meet the requirements of this article or be certified as low risk/cost by the retirement system's chief actuary and board, approved by the Legislature. New members can only join the lower cost formula in place before 2013 or an approved alternative. If a public employer offers a retirement benefit plan before January 1, 2013, consisting solely of a defined contribution plan, they can continue with that plan. However, if they adopt a new defined benefit pension plan or formula after January 1, 2013, it must meet the requirements of this article or be certified as low risk/cost by the retirement system's chief actuary and board, approved by the Legislature. New members can only join the lower cost formula in place before 2013 or an approved alternative. The employer may offer a defined contribution plan on or after January 1, 2013. New members of the employer's plan may only participate in a defined contribution plan that was in place before January 1, 2013, or a plan that meets the requirements of this article. Employers can offer a defined contribution plan on or after January 1, 2013, with or without a defined benefit plan, regardless of previous offerings. If the Cities of Brea and Fullerton form a joint powers authority after January 1, 2013, they may provide employees with the same defined benefit plan they had before joining the authority. This applies to employees from the City of Brea, City of Fullerton, or other specified cities who are not new members and join the joint powers authority within 180 days of the common power being exercised. Employees from specified cities who are not new members can retain their defined benefit plan if they join a joint powers authority within 180 days of the common power being exercised. (2) A city in Orange County contiguous to Brea or Fullerton may join the joint powers authority by January 1, 2017, with a limit of three cities. (3) New members joining a joint powers authority after January 1, 2013, must adhere to the requirements of the article for defined benefit plans. New members joining a joint powers authority after January 1, 2013, must adhere to the requirements of the article for defined benefit plans. The Judges’ Retirement System and the Judges’ Retirement System II are not required to adopt the defined benefit formula or compensation limitations specified in the article. On and after January 1, 2013, public retirement systems must modify their plans to comply with the requirements of this article. Membership in a public retirement system is not provided for individuals ineligible under the system's rules or laws. The Judges’ Retirement System and Judges’ Retirement System II are exempt from adopting certain defined benefit formulas and compensation limitations.
